Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They need to be on time for a scheduled court session that impacts the client’s case
Story: I sat at the edge of the couch, the scent of cinnamon and pine filling the living room as my stepmother called everyone to gather for the annual holiday toast. My father looked at me expectantly, hoping I’d help lead the family in the old tradition, just as he’d asked every year since I moved in. I could see the hope in his eyes, the silent plea to show I belonged, to honor the rituals that made this family whole. But my phone buzzed on the coffee table—a reminder for the court session I was due to attend in less than an hour. My client’s future depended on my presence; missing it could mean a setback they couldn’t afford. My heart pounded as I weighed the warmth of my family’s expectations against the cold, unyielding demands of my profession. I felt split in two, torn between the need to prove I was part of this family and the responsibility to stand up for someone who had no one else. The room grew quieter, all eyes on me, waiting for my choice.
